newsitem.title: USA: Cosby case prosecutors will not seek death penalty.
newsitem.headline: Cosby case prosecutors will not seek death penalty.

text.p: Prosecutors said on Friday that they would not seek the death penalty against the man accused of murdering the only son of entertainer Bill Cosby.

Mihkhail Markhasev, an 18-year-old Ukrainian immigrant charged with the murder of Ennis Cosby on Jan. 16, smiled as the announcement was made at a brief hearing. He also leaned over to his lawyer and appeared to say, "Thank you."
The Los Angeles District Attorney's office "has decided not to pursue the death penalty," Assistant District Attorney Anne Ingalls told Judge John Reid.

California law allows for "special circumstances," or capital punishment, when a murder is committed during a robbery. Police have said they believe Markhasev was trying either to steal Cosby's expensive Mercedes-Benz car or to rob him to get money for drugs.
Cosby was shot while changing a flat tire by the side of a Los Angeles freeway. Markhasev pleaded not guilty at an earlier arraignment.
Cosby's parents, Bill and Camille, said in a brief statement released by their publicist: "We support the District Attorney's decision -- onward to jurisprudence."
At Friday's hearing, which lasted barely one minute, Judge Reid ruled that the murder trial will take place in Santa Monica. He scheduled the next hearing for June 12.
Outside the courtroom Markhasev's court-appointed attorney, Henry Hall, told reporters the prosecutors made "absolutely the right decision.
"This is a case that but for the publicity value would in all circumstances be a life (sentence) case," he said.
Hall said he had not yet decided whether to seek to move the trial out of Los Angeles County entirely.
